name: A Breadth-First Traversable
description:
Write a `Traversable` instance for the following type of Rose Trees which traverses the tree in breadth-first order.

```haskell
data Tree a = a :& [Tree a] deriving (Eq, Ord, Show, Functor)
```

Your instance should be law-abiding.

An automatically derived implementation of `Traversable` performs the effects in depth-first order.

For instance, take the following example tree:

```haskell
exampleTree
  =
    1 :&
      [ 2 :&
          [ 5 :&
              [ 9  :& []
              , 10 :& []]
          , 6 :& []]
      , 3 :& []
      , 4 :&
          [ 7 :&
              [ 11 :& []
              , 12 :& []]
          , 8 :& []]]
```

Calling `bft print exampleTree` should print out the numbers 1 to 12 in order.

You may replace the `Foldable` instance if you like: currently it simply derives the instance from the `Traversable` instance.
